stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the Yoshi-Island overworld, especially parts 6 & 7 around the main Yoshi town. He reviewed an earlier Course-6 beta test, laid out secret-level entrances, and searched for ways to fill a long, empty stretch of land.

development_findings.summary: A private beta of Course 6 ran "super well," signalling that the main courses are now being user-tested.
development_findings.quote: I've had a beta test of course six running today and it went super well.

development_findings.summary: The current task is reshaping Overworld parts 6 & 7, deleting or compressing a long, dull walkway near the Yoshi city and adding meaningful points of interest.
Decided to turn the empty area into an "Athlete Yoshi" sponsorship quest that unlocks the Rainbow Slide secret level once the player has paid coins three times.
development_findings.quote: After he's fully trained, he waves at you… Mario jumps on his back and they jump into the fucking moon.

development_findings.summary: Wants a set of fast, single-mechanic bonus stages (minecart, cloud-cap, rainbow slide, pinball, wing-cap, etc.), each estimated at half a day of work.
development_findings.quote: All of these side levels will be super quick to produce. They all will just take like a day at most.

development_findings.summary: Mario model still lacks final polish (cap-bounce animation, certain shadow effects); Kaze plans to 'finalize' it later the same day.
development_findings.quote: I was about to finalize Mario's model too… probably going to finalize it later today.

development_findings.summary: Uses Fast64 to export levels into the SM64 decompilation; collaborated with the Parallel Launcher maintainer to fix emulator bugs, but the fix was never pushed, so many players couldn't run the demo.
development_findings.quote: A week before the RTYI demo released I fixed it with the guy that maintains Parallel Launcher and then the update didn't get pushed out.

development_findings.summary: Reduced the overall audio code size by reading the full source, ripping out unneeded portions, and fixing the resulting bugs.
development_findings.quote: I actually just read and understood the entire code and then I ripped out everything that seems like it would be unnecessary and then I fixed all the bugs.

development_findings.summary: Actively debating coin-sink design: many small NPC payments vs. one large 'wishing well'–style dump; wants to avoid mandatory grinding.
Plans to display remaining overworld stars per region on the map screen for better player guidance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering moving from ROM hacks to original games after RTYI, potentially opening a studio that releases both fan games and commercial titles.
context_findings.quote: If I make 20 million dollars off of RTYI I'm opening a game studio… real games that were also fan games at the same time.

context_findings.summary: He expects RTYI to be a net financial loss if YouTube and Patreon income are counted separately from the project budget.
context_findings.quote: Definitely RTYI is going to be a net negative after I pay Biobak.

context_findings.summary: Owns two large aquariums and enjoys caring for plecos; briefly paused stream to watch fish eat watermelon.
Frustrated by Nintendo takedowns—71 videos removed—yet notes Nintendo avoids striking the ROM-patches themselves.
context_findings.quote: They took down like everything… 71 are still taken down right now.

context_findings.summary: Expresses deep skepticism toward online statistics and AI-generated discourse, calling recent anti-nuclear messaging a 'chat-GPT powered psyop.'
Not an avid anime watcher; only strongly endorses Hunter x Hunter and early Dragon Ball.

biobak.summary: Kaze confirms that Biobak is a paid contractor and references paying him when discussing project costs.
Appears in chat questioning repetitive coin-for-NPC mechanics, prompting Kaze to refine the design for variety.

zeina.summary: Present off-camera feeding fish and causing phone noise; lightly participates in plugin compatibility discussion.

key_stories.title: Athlete Yoshi & the Rainbow Slide
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to fill a large, boring stretch of land near the Yoshi town. After brainstorming with chat, he devised a coin-sponsored training Yoshi who ultimately propels Mario into a Rainbow Slide race.
key_stories.challenge: An empty overworld segment felt lifeless and design-wise problematic.
key_stories.process: Explored options, rejected cannons and ghost ships, settled on an NPC progression tied to coin payments and visible growth.
key_stories.outcome: A narratively playful mini-quest that also functions as a coin sink and secret-level entrance.
key_stories.key_quote: After he's fully trained… Mario jumps on his back and they jump into the fucking moon.

key_stories.title: Nintendo’s Silent War
key_stories.summary: Kaze revealed that Nintendo has struck 71 of his YouTube videos but has never DMCA-ed the ROM-patches, suggesting the company prefers to avoid testing patch legality.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining online presence while repeated takedowns erase high-view videos.
key_stories.process: Fights individual strikes to restore some uploads; accepts others as permanently lost.
key_stories.outcome: Creates caution and resentment, influences future marketing and distribution thinking.
key_stories.key_quote: They know we can’t touch you here, so we’re gonna touch you here.

key_stories.title: The Parallel Launcher Patch That Didn’t Ship
key_stories.summary: RTYI’s demo failed on the community’s most popular emulator because a last-minute bug-fix never reached users.
key_stories.challenge: Parallel Launcher had bugs that prevented RTYI from running.
key_stories.process: Kaze cooperated with the emulator maintainer and produced a fix one week before release.
key_stories.outcome: Update never pushed, leaving many players unable to play; Kaze fears future plugin regressions.
key_stories.key_quote: It was all around a shit show… I bet by the time the plugin releases it's gonna be broken again.

key_stories.title: Dream of a Hybrid Studio
key_stories.summary: Kaze imagines a company that simultaneously releases a commercial 'Pokémon-like' game and a Pokémon ROM hack as cross-marketing.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a viable path from hobbyist ROM hacking to sustainable indie studio.
key_stories.process: Speculates on RTYI’s potential earnings and how windfall profits could finance both fan and original projects.
key_stories.outcome: Sets long-term aspiration contingent on RTYI’s success.
key_stories.key_quote: How banger would it be if you develop real games that were also fan games at the same time and you released both at once to market each other?

open_questions.context: Kaze debated between multiple small coin sinks (NPC sponsorships) vs. one large 'wishing well' dump, worried about forced grinding.
questions: What is the finalized philosophy for coin usage in RTYI?
How will you balance optional spending so players never feel compelled to grind?
Did Zelda’s single dump model or Mario Sunshine’s blue-coin model influence your decision?

open_questions.context: He listed several fast 'half-day' secret levels (wing-cap, minecart, pinball, etc.) but only partly placed them in the overworld.
questions: Which bonus levels are officially locked in and which are still tentative?
Can you walk us through the design goal of a 'half-day' level?
How do you prevent scope creep while adding these extras?

open_questions.context: RTYI currently struggles on Parallel Launcher despite a patch; Kaze fears future regressions.
questions: What is the roadmap for guaranteed compatibility across major emulators and real hardware?
How did collaboration with the Parallel Launcher maintainer unfold, and what blocked the update?
Would a static recompilation solve these issues permanently?

open_questions.context: Kaze talks about potentially opening a hybrid studio if RTYI earns enough money.
questions: What revenue scenarios would trigger the jump from hobbyist to studio?
How would you navigate legal risks when releasing simultaneous fan and commercial versions?
What roles would Zeina, Biobak, and Badub have in a future studio?

open_questions.context: Model still lacks cap physics and other polish; final pass planned the same day.
questions: What specific technical hurdles remain before the Mario model is locked in?
How does Zeina’s animation workflow integrate with your code and level design?
Are you future-proofing the model for potential ports or higher-resolution hardware?
